documentation.p: Most of the model elements will require a stereotype to be processed correctly, below you will find a table indicating on which model element you may put what stereotype, it will also denote which effect this has on the generation process.

Sometimes it happens you want to add information to the model but there is no clean way of doing it. In those cases you may want to resort to tagged values, but these cases should be considered with caution. A tagged value is something extra, something optional, and the application should run fine without them.
The AngularJS cartridge allows you to add tagged values here and there but provides a default value in case they are missing.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY
element.documentation: Says that an class is an Angularjs factory class.

element.name: ANGULAR_CONTROLLER
element.documentation: Says that an class is an Angularjs Controller class.

element.name: ANGULAR_VIEW
element.documentation: Says that an class is an Angularjs view state.

element.name: ANGULAR_ACTION
element.documentation: Says that an class is an Angularjs Action state.

element.name: FRONT_END_EXCEPTION
element.documentation: Modeled on a transition it designates an exception occuring while processing an action, must exit an action state and enter a <<FrontEndView>>.

element.name: FRONT_END_FIELD
element.documentation: Modeled on a transition it designates an exception occuring while processing an action, must exit an action state and enter a <<FrontEndView>>.

element.name: FRONT_END_REGISTRATION
element.documentation: Modeled on a use case, this stereotype indicates that this use case is a front-end registration wizard. This will cause a link on the login taking the user to this use case.

element.name: FRONT_END_NAVIGATION
element.documentation: Modeled on a use case, this stereotype indicates that this use case is a front-end navigation element. This will cause this use-case to be included in the menu-model for the application.

elementGroup.name: Tagged Values
elementGroup.documentation: AngularJS allows you to add tagged values here and there but provides a default value in the event that they are missing.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_URL
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: name.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_SHOW_PARAMS
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: name.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_DELETE_PARAMS
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: name.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_CREATE
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: name.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_UPDATE
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: UPDATE.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_DELETE
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: delete.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_QUERY
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: query.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_NAME
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: controller name.

element.name: ANGULAR_FACTORY_FACTORY_TYPE
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: factorytype name.

element.name: ANGULAR_VIEW_MASTER
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: controller name.

element.name: ANGULAR_VIEW_DETAIL
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: controller name.

element.name: ANGULAR_VIEW_VIEW_TYPE
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: controller name.

element.name: ANGULAR_VIEW_MODEL
element.documentation: Defines the tagged value: controller name.

element.name: ACTION_TYPE
element.documentation: Modeled on a transition coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype. Indicates the type of trigger causing the action, possible values are hyperlink, image and form. Form is the default value.
element.appliedOnElement: Transition coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: ACTION_TABLELINK
element.documentation: Denotes this action applies on the information shown in a tabular format, you will need to specify the name of the table as the value, optionally suffix with a dot and the name of the column. If the column is specified the action will be rendered in that specific column, otherwise a new column will be created for it.
element.appliedOnElement: Transition coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: VIEW_TYPE
element.documentation: Represents the type of view (regular, popup, etc).

element.name: INPUT_TYPE
element.documentation: Indicates the type of parameter, this information will be used when rendering the views, possible values are: link, multibox, text, textarea, checkbox, radio, select, password, hidden and plaintext.
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: INPUT_RESET
element.documentation: Indicates whether or not the field should be reset (to its orginal value) after the execution of the action. This is useful when you want only some of the parameters reset on the form but not all of them.
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: INPUT_EQUAL
element.documentation: Allows the comparison between 2 fields, this allows you to specify the other field that a parameter must equal in order to be valid (like when comparing two passwords)
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: TABLE_COLUMNS
element.documentation: The collection will be displayed in scrollable tabular format. Each column in this table will be mapped to a property of the object type contained in the collection. So you will need to make sure all objects have accessor methods for the property you list in this tagged value. Properties are separated using a comma ','. More than one value maybe be assigned to this tag, all properties will correctly be resolved.
element.appliedOnElement: A collection type parameter going into an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: TABLE_PAGEABLE
element.documentation: A flag indicating whether or not a table is "pageable". When a table is flagged as "pageable", support for DB paging is generated.
element.appliedOnElement: A collection type parameter going into an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: INPUT_REQUIRED
element.documentation: Denotes whether or not this is a required field. If a field is required its type will always be checked (you cannot enter a String value when an int is expected)
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: INPUT_COLUMN_COUNT
element.documentation: Denotes the number of columns an input field should have.
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: INPUT_ROW_COUNT
element.documentation: Denotes the number of rows on a textarea field.
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype, while having andromda_presentation_web_view_field_textarea

element.name: INPUT_READONLY
element.documentation: Indicates the parameter is read only, it's value cannot be entered by the user
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

element.name: ACTION_FACTORY_BINDING
element.documentation: On action completion will have a success message rendered on screen

allowedValues.value: Any message you would like to see displayed, it will be included in the resource bundle for internationalization

element.name: ACTION_SUCCESS_MESSAGE
element.documentation: On action completion will have a success message rendered on screen

allowedValues.value: Any message you would like to see displayed, it will be included in the resource bundle for internationalization

element.name: ACTION_WARNING_MESSAGE
element.documentation: On action completion will have a warning message rendered on screen

allowedValues.value: Any message you would like to see displayed, it will be included in the resource bundle for internationalization

element.name: INPUT_FORMAT
element.documentation:
The format of this field's value.
Type Value Arguments Example Description
int, float, double, java.lang.Integer, java.lang.Float, java.lang.Double range 2 of this type range 2 12 Specifies in which range the value of this attribute must fall, '-' means no limit so 'range - 10' means any number less than or equal 10
java.lang.String minlength an integer value minlength 4 Specifies the minimum number of characters
java.lang.String maxlength an integer value maxlength 4 Specifies the maximum number of characters
java.lang.String pattern a regular expression pattern [a-zA-Z]* Validates format according to a regular expression (**), the leading '^' and trailing '$' must not be specified
java.lang.String creditcard N/A creditcard Validates the value to be a creditcard number, according to what is known as the Luhn check
java.lang.String email N/A email Checks if the specified value is a possible email address, IP addresses are also taken into account
(*) The format is specified by the java.text.SimpleDateFormat class from the Java 2 SDK, please refer to the JavaDoc documentation of that class for more information, this format is case-sensitive
SimpleDateFormat JavaDoc
(**) The pattern expression is a Perl regular expression as you would you use in Javascript, by convention it requires the ^ and $ to denote respectively the beginning and ending of the pattern
Netscape's guide to regular expressions in Javascript
element.appliedOnElement: Parameter coming out of an action state carrying the <<FrontEndView>> stereotype

allowedValues.value: Any of the formats listed above

element.name: MANAGEABLE_MAXIMUM_LIST_SIZE
element.documentation: The maximum number of rows to fetch from the database in a single operation. Tune this parameter to avoid downloading thousands of rows each time, most of the time the user will want to use the search facility to refine the result set

element.name: MANAGEABLE_PAGE_SIZE
element.documentation: The maximum number of records to show on the same page.

element.name: MANAGEABLE_DISPLAY_NAME
element.documentation: The column representing this entity,by default the first <<Unique>> attribute found is taken but you might want to specify another column yourself. This value is used when one entity has a foreign key to another one and you want to select the value of this foreign key from a combobox and you would like to see a more meaningful label for each option, if no <<Unique>> attribute is found the identifier is used, which isn't very helpful.

allowedValues.value: any column name present in this entity
the name of the identifier column
